metadata.title: Peripheral Nerve Injury
anatomical location body part affected: Variable, depending upon location of affected nerve(s) and severity of injury. Nerves that are more superficial are more vulnerable to injury
description: Classification of nerve injuries –There are three types of nerve injuries(1) -Neuropraxia -Intact -Transient (few days to months) paralysis due to conduction block at site of injury -Axonotmesis -Axon and myelin disrupted, but the endoneurial tube remains intact -Slower recovery than neuropraxia -Neurotmesis -Complete transection of the axon, myelin, and neuronal connective tissue -There is no recovery without surgical repair –Another type of classification of nerve injuries is suggested by Sunderland and is based on the severity of the injury(6) -1st degree—similar to a neurapraxia -2nd and 3rd degree—disruption of the axon; similar to axonotmesis -4th degree—disruption of axon, endoneurium, and perineurium. Usually requires surgery -5th degree—complete loss of continuity of nerve in fifth degree similar to neurotmesis. Usually requires surgery

presentation signs and symptoms: Presentation differs according to the degree of injury and the nerve affected. Loss of motor function and/or sensory function in the neural distribution will occur,as will a flaccid paralysis of the muscles innervated by the nerve injured Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: peripheral nerve lesions occur f: laceration/puncture – can be associated with surgical procedures
pathogenesis: Denervation results from loss of transmission due to injury to or complete disruption of nerve fibers at various locations,including–motor neurons in the spinal cord or ventral root–cauda equina–motor fibers in peripheral nerves

Neural response to injury(7)–In the first few days after injury, local degeneration includes retrograde and anterograde degeneration of axon and myelin–After a few days and up to weeks, the anterograde pattern of Wallerian degeneration is completed. Macrophagescontribute to the removal of tissue debris and Schwann cells undergo mitosis–The severed proximal end of the axon develops regenerative axonal sprouts, which may reach appropriate endoneurialtubes and continue to extend through the distal nerve stump–If the regenerative axonal sprouts do not succeed in crossing the injury site, a neuroma will form–Nerve growth factor and glial-derived  neurotrophic factor are important to nerve repair as a stimulus for growth of theaxons

Neuromuscular junction and muscle response to peripheral nerve injury(8)–Instability of the neuromuscular junction develops–Muscles atrophy, muscle fiber diameter gradually decreases, and muscle conduction velocity decreases–Denervated muscle fiber cell membranes spontaneously discharge, causing an unstable resting membrane or fibrillationpotential–Once reinnervation occurs, the fibrillation potential decreases and fully disappears upon complete healing
risk factors: Trauma–Approximately 1.6% of all individuals with a traumatic injury sustain peripheral nerve damage(2)-Motor vehicle accidents are a prime cause-Approximately 1.9% of crush injuries result in damage to a peripheral nerve-Approximately 1.5% of joint dislocations have an associated nerve injury

Surgery(9)–Peripheral nerve injury is present after < 1% of surgical procedures, with higher incidence in cardiac, neurosurgical, andsome orthopedic procedures–Injuries to the brachial plexus and ulnar nerves represent two-thirds  of claims for peripheral nerve injuries that occurredunder anesthesia

overall contraindications precautions: If patient is in immediate postoperative stage of rehabilitation following nerve repair, avoid applying tensile force at the repair site. Observe physician’s guidelines and/or postsurgical protocol
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Describe mechanism of injury  laceration, compression, contusion, ischemic, stretch/elongation, etc. -When was onset? -What are current symptoms? Note progression/changes in symptoms since onset -Document coexisting injuries and their status

course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? OTC or prescription pain medication might be recommended
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Electrodiagnostic testing generally is conducted 34 weeks post injury to avoid misleading results and to allow for spontaneous recovery(7)

Denervation is indicated by presence of low amplitude sharp waves or fibrillations with muscle at restand absent evoked muscle action potentials. Fibrillations typically become apparent after 2–3weeks, although researchers have reported that they are evident after 1 week(8)
With reinnervation these changes begin to reverse
In 1st degree injuries (neuropraxia), signal is normal distal to the lesion and abnormal across the area of conduction block
In 2nd, 3rd, and 4th degree injuries, NCV is absent distal to the lesion and returns to normal as reinnervation occurs
In 5th degree (neurotmesis) injury, NCV is absent distal to the lesion and does not recover without successful surgical intervention
In axonal injury the compound muscle action potential is present in the first week and thereafter falls rapidly after Wallerian degeneration has occurred
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -Document specific motor loss -Document sensory changes
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/nightDocument if patient requires supplemental oxygen, ventilation, asthma treatment, etc.
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document previous peripheral nerve injury, if any, and result of treatment
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she might be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the injury affect ability to perform job or recreational activities? Do job or recreational activities require repetitive movements?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, etc.). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document and measure area(s) of muscle atrophy/wasting and/or edema
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate splints and/or sling for proper fit and use. Assess the need for additional devices for assistance with ambulation or ADLs
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance for both lower and upper extremity injury –Reduced upper extremity movements might impact postural and balance functions
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulses and capillary filling of hands or feet, as indicated Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity –Assess integrity of cranial nerves –Peripheral nerve integrity testing -Motor function. Manual or dynamometry testing along the motor distribution of a nerve, if appropriate. Observe for deviations during movement -Sensory function. Test for sensory changes along the distribution of a nerve with a peripheral nerve injury, if appropriateAssess efficiency and efficacy of movementsA functional assessment should be conducted, if indicated. The FIM can be utilized, if appropriate
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Full gait assessment, including gait speed, should be conducted, if indicated. The 10MWT can be used to assess gait speed. Would patient benefit from an orthotic or assistive device?Joints local to site of injury should be screenedNote substitute movements. Assess coordination of affected extremity
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle function with MMT –Dynamometer and pinch grip test might be performed if hand is affected –Functional strength (hop, triple hop, etc.) testing for lower extremity injuries might be performed, if possible
observation inspection palpation includi: Edema from associated trauma should be noted
Status of postoperative incisions should be documented and monitored
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: A complete ROM assessment should be conducted of the affected limb and spine
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Document appropriate reflex responseAssess ability to use the affected limb
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: A complete sensory and somatosensory profile of the affected area should be conducted along the distribution of the affected nerve(s)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Tinel’s sign – lightly tapping over the nerve to illicit sensation or tingling -1st degree injury – not present -2nd and 3rd degree injuries – can be used to monitor location of injury and progress of regenerating nerve in 2nd and 3rd degree injuries  -4th and 5th degree injuries – Tinel’s sign present at site of injury, advancement does not occur

contraindications precautions: Restoration and maintenance of ROM is essential
in an area with infection or bleeding
if a tumor is present in the area
Individuals who cannot communicate effectively (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis might be at risk for falls; follow facility protocol for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Denervated limbs are susceptible to muscle and joint contracture
Compressive forces over healing or regenerating nerves should be avoided
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications; do not use:(3)

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy might be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(3)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Peripheral nerve injury causes loss of motor function, sensory function, or both. The patient might benefit from treatment to improve strength, functional mobility, ROM, flexibility, balance, and the ability to ambulate and perform ADLs, depending on the location and severity of the injury
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Diabetic or other neuropathy Neuromuscular disease (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis [ALS], multiple sclerosis [MS]) Neoplasm CNS injury or disease
prognosis: Essentially complete recovery is expected following 1st and 2nd degree injuries
Proximal nerve injuries require extended time for nerve regeneration
Reinnervation might not occur quickly enough to prevent permanent muscle function loss

Researchers found that approximately half of patients with finger nerve injury had good functional outcomes at 9 months(5) –By 9 months, the patients had approximately half the strength in their affected hands as compared to their unaffected hands
Patients with peripheral nerve injuries that require surgery have useful function after the procedure in 50% of cases(7)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Occupational therapist (OT) for evaluation of functional ADLs and/or fabrication of splints Certified hand therapist (OT or physical therapist [PT]) if specialized knowledge is required following a hand injury
other considerations: Functional electrical stimulation (FES) –FES is suggested to counteract the muscle atrophy that accompanies denervation(10) –A triangular pulse of 200 ms duration with the cathode proximal is suggested for the best stimulation of a denervated tibialis anterior muscle as it requires the lowest current intensity(10) –There is still a lack of scientific evidence for electrical stimulation as a way to prevent atrophy in human muscles that are denervated, although it has been shown in animal models(11)
treatment summary: ROM exercises –Following a period of initial immobilization after surgery, ROM exercises are used to restore limb mobility -Site of repair protected for up to 14 days
Support devices –Splints, slings, and/or braces might be used to support the denervated body part to help prevent contracture, subluxation, and deformity and to mitigate functional loss

Sensorimotor reeducation following surgery begins when evidence of reinnervation is noted –Biofeedback -Biofeedback has been suggested as a useful adjunct during rehabilitation of peripheral nerve injuries –Patients who received a 12-week  touch observation and task-based  mirror therapy were found to improve more in a pinch-holding-up  activity test and the Purdue Pegboard Test when compared to controls(12) -Based on an RCT conducted in Taiwan with 12 patients with median and ulnar nerve repair -No differences in groups were found on the Semmes-Weinstein  monofilament test –However, results from another RCT using only mirror therapy indicated no significant difference in Rosen Score after 5 months of treatment when compared to classic sensory reeducation(13) -Based on a study conducted in Brazil with 20 patients with median and ulnar nerve and flexor tendon repair .
